abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> syndrome is an inherited condition associated with an increased risk of developing hamartomatous and neoplastic lesions in diverse organs, mainly at early ages. Germline pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> cause this condition. Detecting a variant of uncertain significance in <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> or finding uncommon phenotypes complicate the diagnosis and can negatively impact patient care. We present two unrelated patients suspected to have DICER1 syndrome. Both females (aged 13 and 15 years) presented with multinodular goiter (thyroid follicular nodular disease) and ovarian tumours. One was diagnosed with an ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour (SLCT) and the other, with an ovarian juvenile granulosa cell tumour, later reclassified as a retiform variant of SLCT. Genetic screening showed no germline pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic>. However, two potentially splicing variants were found, <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> c.5365-4A>G and c.5527+3A>G. Also, typical somatic <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> RNase IIIb hotspot mutations were detected in the thyroid and ovarian tissues. In silico splicing algorithms predicted altered splicing for both germline variants and skipping of exon 25 was confirmed by RNA assays for both variants. The reclassification of the ovarian tumour, leading to recognition of the association with DICER1 syndrome and the characterization of the germline intronic variants were all applied to recently described <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> variant classification rules. This ultimately resulted in confirmation of DICER1 syndrome in the two teenage girls.
</jats:p>

assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest with regard to this work.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study followed the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. Approval was granted by the McGill University Faculty of Medicine Institutional Review Board (A08-M61-09B).

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All participants and/or their legal guardians provided written informed consent to participate in the study and they accepted the publication of the data.

title: Reclassification of two germline DICER1 splicing variants leads to DICER1 syndrome diagnosis
